simple.title: Time Series Pie Chart
simple.text:
This is a new visualization of pie chart which shows data changes over time.

Dataset: The graph shows the number of each type of house sold from 2007 to 2012

simple.title: Current Year Label
simple.text: This shows the current highlighted year.

simple.title: Current Selected Year
simple.text: All the data from the current year are fully highlighted

simple.title: One Category Over Time
simple.text:
This is the section of the pie chart for 3-bedroom house sold.

The area of each arc (not the height) is porportional to the revenue of sales from that year.

simple.title: Hover on Arc
simple.text:
Hover over the highlighted arc. The tooltip shows that in 2012 3% of the total houses sold were 1-bedroom houses.

There was only one 1-bedroom house sold in 2012, and it sold for 527k

simple.title: Click on Arc
simple.text:
You can changing the selected year by clicking on a new arc.

For example, Click on this arc to change from 2007 to 2012

simple.title: Double Click on Arc to Compare
simple.text:
The average price per unit is proportional to the height of the arc.

You can compare all arcs' average selling price in a given year by double click on any arc of that year to align the bases.

Try yourself by double clicking on this arc to compare all arcs in 2012

simple.title: Click Again on Current Year's Arc to reset
simple.text:
To reset the visualization, simply click on any arc for the given year

Try yourself by clicking on this arc to reset the visualization

simple.title: Legends
simple.text: Here is the list of categories for the house data

simple.title: Click on Legend
simple.text:
You can click on any category to go to the earliest year where the house type appears in the data

Click on the 2-bedroom label to go to 2008's visualization (2 bedroom houses were first sold in 2008)

simple.title: Recap
simple.text:
The angle of a wedge represents the number of units sold in that type/year.

The area represents the total revenue from those sales.

As a result, the tall wedges are those with high revenue (area) but low units sold (angle), leading to a higher average price per unit
